# Question

Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

```julia-repl
function wrap_string(str, text_width = 10)
    result = ""
    current_line_length = 0
    for word in split(str," ")
        if (current_line_length + length(word)) > text_width
            result *= "\n"
            current_line_length = 0
        end
        result *= word*" "
        current_line_length += length(word)
    end
    return rstrip(result) # remove trailing spaces
end
```

Example:

```julia-repl
# Define a long string for testing
str = "This is a very long sentence that will be wrapped"

# Call the function with different text widths
println("Text Width 10:")
println(wrap_string(str, 10))
println("\nText Width 5:")
println(wrap_string(str, 5))
```

Output:
```
Text Width 10:
This is a very long sentence that will be wrapped

Text Width 5:
This is
a very long
sentence
that will
be wrapped
```

This function iterates over the words in `str` using `split(str," ")` and checks if the current length of the line plus the length of the word would exceed the maximum text width. If it does, it adds a newline to the result string. Otherwise, it appends the word and a space.
